custom_fields.key_topics: Cost Classifications; Short-term Decision Making; Cost Allocations; Activity-Based Costing; Budgeting; Variance Analysis; Capital Budgeting; Business Units Performance Measurement; Transfer Pricing; Non-Financial Measures and the Balanced Score Card.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: In addition to course prereqs, students should be familiar with Excel and reading financial accounting spreadsheets.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: The course assesses the performance of students with problem sets and exams. There is a mid-term and a final exam. There are no group projects, but students are encouraged to work on problem sets together. However, each student must submit separate and unique solution. Participation in class discussions is also encouraged and is part of the grade.
custom_fields.goals: This course has a very practical approach to business decision making. It aims to provide students with an intuitive ability to assess business situations. We are not striving for the perfect or optimal decision making tool, but for practical and economically sound decisions that will be applicable in the real world.
custom_fields.relevance: This course teaches you how to take business decisions. We cover essential decision making that any manager, entrepreneur, or consultant should know. If you do not understand the material in this course, you will not be able to assess whether your business decisions make sense, and will not foresee the consequences of your choices for the bottom line.
custom_fields.learning_resources: There is a textbook for the course, and handouts that collectively fill up in during the class sessions.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Homework, and optional review sessions before exams.

long_desc: The purpose of this course is to prepare students to make sensible business decisions using accounting information. An essential topic in the course is the measurement and allocation of costs to assist decision making in organizations. The course covers standard topics in cost accounting, such as cost behavior and relevant costs, and connect these to broader issues in microeconomics, decision theory, corporate  finance, and operations management. Classes contain a mixture of conventional lectures, problem solving, business cases,  and simulations. This course may use thirdparty course material that is not available for individual purchase from the publisher.   If so, the thirdparty course material will be secured and provided by the Tepper School to students enrolled in the course, and students enrolled in the course will be required to pay to the University the associated additional course materials fee for the thirdparty course material provided.   The amount of the course materials fee is dependent on the Universitys cost of the particular materials provided, and typically ranges from 13 to 75.
